content.description: <math alttext="H F aqueous plus H 2 O liquid is in equilibrium with H 3 O with a positive 1 charge aqueous plus F with a negative 1 charge aqueous. p K sub a equals 3.20 at 25 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="2.0em"></mspace><mtext>p</mtext><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>3.20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>at</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>⁢</mo><mn>25</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: The acid ionization equilibrium for the weak acid <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented by the equation above. To prepare a buffer with a <math alttext="p H equals 3.50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>3.50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, a student needs to mix <math alttext="250 decimal point milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>250.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.100 molar H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="250 decimal point milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>250.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.100 molar K F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>KF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. If the student mistakenly mixes <math alttext="250 decimal point milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>250.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.0500 molar H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="250 decimal point milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>250.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.0500 molar K F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>KF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which of the following is the result of this error?

choices.label: The buffer will have a lower capacity because of the smaller number of moles of <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F with a negative 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> available to react if an acid or base is added.

The buffer will have a lower capacity because the smaller amount of <math alttext="H F " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F with a negative 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> will lower the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the buffer, and buffers of lower <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> have a lower buffer capacity.

The buffer will have a higher capacity because a larger proportion of <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F with a negative 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> will ionize at lower concentrations, resulting in the neutralization of any added acid or base.
The buffer will have the same capacity because the large volume of the buffer solution dilutes any added acid or base.

content.answer: The buffer will have a lower capacity because of the smaller number of moles of <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F with a negative 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> available to react if an acid or base is added.

skill.text: 6.G: Explain how potential sources of experimental error may affect the experimental results.
